summary.text_en: Tycho Brahe was the 'king of astronomical observation' and the critical link between Copernicus and Kepler. Funded by the King of Denmark, he built Uraniborg, the most advanced astronomical observatory in the world. *Without* a telescope, he built giant, precision instruments and conducted 20 years of systematic, high-accuracy observations. He amassed a massive database on planetary motion (especially Mars) with an unprecedented accuracy of 1-2 arcminutes. It was this data that later allowed his assistant, Johannes Kepler, to derive the 'Three Laws of Planetary Motion'.
key_points_en: Amassed 20+ years of hyper-accurate planetary data
His data was the basis for Kepler's Laws

story.text_en: Tycho's revolution was *method*. Before him, astronomers only observed special events (like eclipses or conjunctions). Tycho was the first to see the value of *continuous, systematic observation*. He recorded the exact positions of planets (especially Mars) night after night, like an accountant, correcting for errors like atmospheric refraction. His goal was to create a perfect new star catalog to replace Ptolemy and Copernicus and (he hoped) to reform astrology. He also created the 'Tychonic System', a compromise model where the Sun orbits the Earth, but all other planets orbit the Sun. It was wrong, but a popular model at the time.

fun_facts.text_en: Tycho lost part of his nose in a duel (allegedly over a mathematical formula) and wore a prosthetic nose made of brass and silver for the rest of his life.
Tycho owned a pet moose. According to Kepler, the moose drank too much beer at a banquet, fell down a flight of stairs, and died.
His observation of the 1572 'New Star' (a supernova) proved it was *beyond* the Moon, shattering the Aristotelian dogma that the heavens were perfect and unchanging.

simple_explanation.text_en: Tycho was the 'data king' or 'database administrator' of science. Before him, people like Copernicus were 'theorists' working with bad data. Tycho said, 'We need to stop guessing and start *measuring*.' He spent 20 years building the biggest, most precise instruments (like giant protractors) to log exactly where Mars was, night after night. He couldn't solve the puzzle himself, but after he died, his assistant, Kepler, 'inherited' this database and used it to *finally* figure out the true laws of how planets move (ellipses).

applications.text_en: Without Tycho's data, Kepler would have *never* discovered that orbits are elliptical. The 8-arcminute discrepancy that obsessed Kepler was Tycho's margin of error.

applications.text_en: His parallax measurements of the 1572 Supernova and the Great Comet of 1577 proved they were far beyond the Moon, irrefutably proving Aristotle's 'unchanging heavens' was wrong.

impact.text_en: Tycho Brahe was the empirical founder of the Scientific Revolution. He transformed astronomy from a discipline of philosophical speculation and crude calculation into a rigorous science dependent on systematic, high-precision observational data. He provided the 'ammunition' (data) that Kepler used to 'destroy' the old cosmological models, paving the way for Newton's physical revolution.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Copernicus (whose heliocentric model was the primary theory Tycho was trying to test, fix, or disprove)
Ptolemy (whose data in the 'Almagest' was the old standard Tycho sought to surpass and replace)

influenced.contribution_en: Johannes Kepler (his assistant, who inherited his entire life's work of data and used it to discover the laws of planetary motion)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Tycho proved that precise, massive 'data' is, by itself, the most powerful weapon for overthrowing old theories and building new ones.

options_en: He provided 20+ years of hyper-accurate observational data of the planets
quiz.explanation_en: Tycho did not support the Heliocentric model (he had his own compromise system), and all his work was done with the naked eye *before* the telescope. His true legacy was the 'data'â€”without this precise data, Kepler could have never proven that orbits were elliptical.
